articles.headline: An Electric Boost for Bicyclists
articles.snippet: The booming Chinese electric-bike industry is spurring impressive sales in India, Europe and the U.S.
articles.abstract: The booming Chinese electric-bike industry is spurring impressive sales in India, Europe and the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Jiang Ruming, a marketing manager, owns a van, but for many errands, he hops on a futuristic-looking contraption that lets him weave rapidly through Shanghai’s messy traffic. He rides an electric bicycle.

articles.headline: Risky Trading Wasn’t Just on the Fringe at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The conventional wisdom was that risky derivatives from a London unit brought down A.I.G. But a Delaware division was gambling as well.
articles.abstract: The conventional wisdom was that risky derivatives from a London unit brought down A.I.G. But a Delaware division was gambling as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the American International Group nearly collapsed, the conventional wisdom has been that the exotic derivatives that drove it to the brink were the product of a lone, unregulated subsidiary in London. The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, called the London branch “a hedge fund, basically, attached to a large and stable insurance company.”

articles.headline: F.D.A. Aims at Doctors’ Drug Pitches
articles.snippet: Dr. Leslie Baumann’s comments in the media about an antiwrinkle drug violated restrictions on drug promotion, the agency said, in what is believed to be the first time an individual researcher was warned.
articles.abstract: Dr. Leslie Baumann’s comments in the media about an antiwrinkle drug violated restrictions on drug promotion, the agency said, in what is believed to be the first time an individual researcher was warned.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the rarefied world of fashion magazines, beauty editors have often relied on a coterie of prominent dermatologists and plastic surgeons to keep them current on advances in cosmetic medicine. This symbiotic relationship has benefited magazines eager for beauty scoops and doctors seeking visibility  and patients.

articles.headline: To Deliver, iPad Needs Media Deals
articles.snippet: The iPad is a device for consuming media, not creating it. So are the media providers ready to do business?
articles.abstract: The iPad is a device for consuming media, not creating it. So are the media providers ready to do business?
articles.lead_paragraph: Short of landing in a flying saucer and having a tablet teleported into his hands, there was no way that Steve Jobs could have lived up to the hype before last Wednesday’s iPad announcement.

articles.headline: Editorial Shake-Up as Harper’s Tries to Stabilize in a Downturn
articles.snippet: The publisher and main benefactor raises concerns that the magazine, a nonprofit supported by his foundation, is becoming irrelevant.
articles.abstract: The publisher and main benefactor raises concerns that the magazine, a nonprofit supported by his foundation, is becoming irrelevant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just before noon last Wednesday, John R. MacArthur, the president, publisher and chief benefactor of Harper’s Magazine, joined his editorial staff after its monthly meeting.

articles.headline: Men Defend Historic Mandela Site ... From Rabbits
articles.snippet: The island where Nelson Mandela spent years in prison is overrun with rabbits, leading to a gory solution.
articles.abstract: The island where Nelson Mandela spent years in prison is overrun with rabbits, leading to a gory solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa  This dollop of land, just 1 mile wide and 2 miles long, is where Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison. Now venerated as a World Heritage Site, it is one of South Africa’s biggest tourist attractions, with 1,200 or so people each day boarding ferries in Cape Town that in 45 minutes carry them back into history.

articles.headline: U.S. Examines Whether Blackwater Tried Bribery
articles.snippet: The inquiry will look into whether Blackwater officials used bribes to retain work after a 2007 shooting in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The inquiry will look into whether Blackwater officials used bribes to retain work after a 2007 shooting in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department is investigating whether officials of Blackwater Worldwide tried to bribe Iraqi government officials in hopes of retaining the firm’s security work in Iraq after a deadly shooting episode in 2007, according to current and former government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and James Risen

articles.headline: Toyota’s Slow Awakening to a Deadly Problem
articles.snippet: A fatal accident in August led Toyota to step up its inquiry of unintended acceleration, yet only last week did it come to terms with the problem’s scope.
articles.abstract: A fatal accident in August led Toyota to step up its inquiry of unintended acceleration, yet only last week did it come to terms with the problem’s scope.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The 911 call came at 6:35 p.m. on Aug. 28 from a car that was speeding out of control on Highway 125 near San Diego.

articles.headline: Publisher Wins Fight With Amazon Over E-Books
articles.snippet: In a strongly worded message, Amazon said that while it disagreed with Macmillan’s stance, it would accept the publisher’s plan on e-book prices.
articles.abstract: In a strongly worded message, Amazon said that while it disagreed with Macmillan’s stance, it would accept the publisher’s plan on e-book prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a weekend of brinksmanship, Amazon.com on Sunday surrendered to a publisher and agreed to raise prices on some electronic books.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Forces Pushing Obama on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
articles.snippet: Pushed by a critical interest group and finding a new tone in the Pentagon, the administration is ready to act.
articles.abstract: Pushed by a critical interest group and finding a new tone in the Pentagon, the administration is ready to act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and top Pentagon officials met repeatedly over the past year about repealing “don’t ask, don’t tell,” the law that bans openly gay members of the military.

articles.headline: With Eye on Its Reputation, Toyota Issues Repair for Pedal
articles.snippet: The parts for the gas pedal solution are on their way to dealers, whose staffs are being trained for a process that takes about a half-hour.
articles.abstract: The parts for the gas pedal solution are on their way to dealers, whose staffs are being trained for a process that takes about a half-hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT    Toyota, struggling to eliminate questions surrounding millions of its vehicles, announced a repair on Monday to stop gas pedals from possibly sticking and causing cars to speed up unexpectedly.
